Question 218:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ čhéeli míi thaní maníit-u síinta ba xálak les mhaar-éen
Gloss (with missing item): ___ goat 1SG.GEN QUOT say.PFV"=MSG CONDH TOP people 3SG.DIST.ACC kill-3PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`If I now say ``This is my sheep'', people will kill him.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Some clauses with a~predictive semantics are coded in the same manner, either with the `when'/`if'-clause in the perfective (\ref{ex:13-99}) or in the future (\ref{ex:13-100}), although most predictions tend to be coded as hypothetical conditionals (see below). Again, the choice between the two is most likely to do with the degree of predictability, although in some predictive contexts the two codings are used more or less interchangeably.
A: word: típa	 gloss: now
B: word: thée	 gloss: then
C: word: páand-a	 gloss: path-OBL
D: word: rumiaál	 gloss: handkerchief
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 225:

The English translation of this sentence is:`When I come, at whatever time during the night, and knock, you should come out, and we will go to work.'

Again, the choice between the two is most likely to do with the degree of predictability, although in some predictive contexts the two codings are used more or less interchangeably.

D: word: trók-i	 gloss: weak-F
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Correct Answer: B

Question 229:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ma róot-a ɡá=ɡala ṭeem-íi ___ ma tu the ṭaak-úum seentá tu nikh-á ta kráam-a the b-áaya
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG.NOM night-OBL what=ever time-GEN ___ 1SG.NOM 2SG.NOM to call-1SG CONDH 2SG.NOM come.out--IMP.SG SUB work-OBL to come-1PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`When I come, at whatever time during the night, and knock, you should come out, and we will go to work.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Some clauses with a~predictive semantics are coded in the same manner, either with the `when'/`if'-clause in the perfective (\ref{ex:13-99}) or in the future (\ref{ex:13-100}), although most predictions tend to be coded as hypothetical conditionals (see below). Again, the choice between the two is most likely to do with the degree of predictability, although in some predictive contexts the two codings are used more or less interchangeably.
A: word: whaí	 gloss: come.down.CV
B: word: whaal-éen	 gloss: bring.down.3PL
C: word: phaí	 gloss: girl[\textbf{F}]
D: word: yhaí	 gloss: come.CV
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

An example of the latter is (\ref{ex:13-102}).

Question 236:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ heenṣúka paás bhíl-a heentá ɡhróom-a iskuul-í the wh-áaya
Gloss (with missing item): ___ this.year pass become.PFV"=MPL CONDL village-OBL school-OBL to come.down-1PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`If we, God willing, pass this year, we will come down to the village school.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Hypothetical conditionality.} These conditionals belong mainly under the imaginative type, following \citeauthor{thompsonetal2007}'s (\citeyear[259--260]{thompsonetal2007}) classification. Examples (\ref{ex:13-103})--(\ref{ex:13-104}) express conditions of a~lower verisimilitude than the assumed conditionals above. The conditionally"=marked clause of this kind, often translatable with `if{\ldots}', is a~finite (often perfective) clause with the conditionality marker heentá, followed by an~imperfective `then'-clause. They describe a~condition that is probable or possible, although to a~certain extent imagined. Most conditionals referring to the future are also coded this way.
A: word: paalaá	 gloss: leaf
B: word: kh-ainíi	 gloss: eat-VN
C: word: xudaái	 gloss: God
D: word: inšaalaáh	 gloss: God.willing
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 245:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dúu ǰáan-a akaadúi xox ___ heentá se bhraawú bh-áan-a bhraawéeli th-áan-a
Gloss (with missing item): two person-PL RECP liking ___ CONDL 3PL.NOM brother.PL become-PRS"=MPL brotherhood do-PRS"=MPL
The English translation of this sentence is:`If two persons like one another, they become brothers, they form a~brotherhood.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Hypothetical conditionality.} These conditionals belong mainly under the imaginative type, following \citeauthor{thompsonetal2007}'s (\citeyear[259--260]{thompsonetal2007}) classification. Examples (\ref{ex:13-103})--(\ref{ex:13-104}) express conditions of a~lower verisimilitude than the assumed conditionals above. The conditionally"=marked clause of this kind, often translatable with `if{\ldots}', is a~finite (often perfective) clause with the conditionality marker heentá, followed by an~imperfective `then'-clause. They describe a~condition that is probable or possible, although to a~certain extent imagined. Most conditionals referring to the future are also coded this way.
A: word: bh-íl-a	 gloss: become-PFV"=MPL
B: word: čhéeli	 gloss: goat
C: word: bhíl-i	 gloss: become.PFV-F
D: word: bhíl-a	 gloss: become.PFV"=MPL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 246:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): dúu ǰáan-a akaadúi xox bhíl-a ___ se bhraawú bh-áan-a bhraawéeli th-áan-a
Gloss (with missing item): two person-PL RECP liking become.PFV"=MPL ___ 3PL.NOM brother.PL become-PRS"=MPL brotherhood do-PRS"=MPL
The English translation of this sentence is:`If two persons like one another, they become brothers, they form a~brotherhood.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Hypothetical conditionality.} These conditionals belong mainly under the imaginative type, following \citeauthor{thompsonetal2007}'s (\citeyear[259--260]{thompsonetal2007}) classification. Examples (\ref{ex:13-103})--(\ref{ex:13-104}) express conditions of a~lower verisimilitude than the assumed conditionals above. The conditionally"=marked clause of this kind, often translatable with `if{\ldots}', is a~finite (often perfective) clause with the conditionality marker the morpheme ___, followed by an~imperfective `then'-clause. They describe a~condition that is probable or possible, although to a~certain extent imagined. Most conditionals referring to the future are also coded this way.
A: word: síinta	 gloss: CONDH
B: word: seentá	 gloss: CONDH
C: word: íṇc̣-a	 gloss: bear-OBL
D: word: heentá	 gloss: CONDL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

The English translation of this sentence is:`If you don't take these [to her], I will ask you on the day of judgment.'

Question 252:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. The English translation of this sentence is:`If you were to make a~veranda, the wood used for the veranda should be a bit different from that used for the house.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: As with assumed conditionality, the clause"=final conditional marker also co"=occurs with a~temporal conjunction in some instances of hypothetical conditionality, as can be seen in (\ref{ex:13-106}).

Question 256:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): ___ this.year pass become.PFV"=MPL CONDL village-OBL school-OBL to come.down-1PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`If we, God willing, pass this year, we will come down to the village school.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Besides the `then'-clauses in (\ref{ex:13-103})--(\ref{ex:13-106}) with Future and Present, respectively, the Imperative as well as the Simple Past are possible to use in future"=referring `then'-clauses, both occurring in (\ref{ex:13-107}).
A: word: paalaá	 gloss: leaf
B: word: kanáa	 gloss: like.what
C: word: inšaalaáh	 gloss: God.willing
D: word: xudaái	 gloss: God
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 266:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ki ___ múṛ-u heentá ḍhanɡ-á anú ǰáand-u ba dharíit-u heentá asím tu the baxíl-u
Gloss (with missing item): COMP ___ die.PFV"=MSG CONDL bury-IMP.SG 3MSG.PROX.NOM alive-MSG TOP remain.PFV"=MSG CONDL 1PL.ERG 1SG.NOM to donate.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`If he dies, then bury him, if he instead stays alive, then he will remain with you [lit: we entrusted him to you].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Besides the `then'-clauses in (\ref{ex:13-103})--(\ref{ex:13-106}) with Future and Present, respectively, the Imperative as well as the Simple Past are possible to use in future"=referring `then'-clauses, both occurring in (\ref{ex:13-107}).
A: word: hanú	 gloss: 3MSG.PROX.NOM
B: word: anú	 gloss: 3MSG.PROX.NOM
C: word: eesó	 gloss: 3MSG.REM.NOM
D: word: bh-áan-u	 gloss: become-PRS"=MSG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 274:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ phoó na d-áan-a heentá ma pirsaahíb haṛáyuu traṭáa th-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): ___ boy NEG give-PRS"=MPL CONDL 1SG.NOM Pir.Sahib from.there expulsion do-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Unless they hand over the boy, I will expel Pir Sahib from there.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Quite infrequently, the `if'-clause occurs in a~TMA category other than the perfective categories. The utterance in (\ref{ex:13-108}) is in effect a~threat, while the utterance in (\ref{ex:13-109}) is a~polite request.
A: word: akáaš	 gloss: eleven
B: word: haṛé	 gloss: DIST
C: word: aṛé	 gloss: DIST{\protect\footnotemark}
D: word: zindá	 gloss: life
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 279:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ tu na khaá ba kaseé the uṛ-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 2SG.NOM NEG eat.CV TOP someone.ACC to let.out-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`If I don't eat you, I leave you to someone else [i.e., someone else will eat you].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Apart from the explicitly the morpheme ___rked Conditional clauses exemplified above, we also find conditionality implied in Converb clauses, as in (\ref{ex:13-110}), as well as in ta-clauses, as in (\ref{ex:13-111}). The Past Imperfective in the `then'-clause in (\ref{ex:13-111}) implies unfulfilment.
A: word: maníit-u	 gloss: say.PFV"=MSG
B: word: iškaarí	 gloss: hunter
C: word: ma	 gloss: 1SG.NOM
D: word: muaaf-í	 gloss: forgiveness-PL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 286:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): companion-PL.OBL to ___ PST SUB corpse throw-CV flee-3PL PST
The English translation of this sentence is:`If I told my companions, they may run away and leave the dead body.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Apart from the explicitly marked Conditional clauses exemplified above, we also find conditionality implied in Converb clauses, as in (\ref{ex:13-110}), as well as in ta-clauses, as in (\ref{ex:13-111}). The Past Imperfective in the `then'-clause in (\ref{ex:13-111}) implies unfulfilment.
A: word: máa=ee	 gloss: 1SG.NOM=CNJ
B: word: th-áam	 gloss: do-1SG
C: word: man-úum	 gloss: say-1SG
D: word: d-úum	 gloss: give-1SG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 294:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ma islaamabaad-á ɡáu de heentá šuy bhíl-u de heentá islaamabaád dhríiṣṭ-u de heentá
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 1SG.NOM Islamabad-OBL go.PFV.MSG PST CONDL good become.PFV"=MSG PST CONDL Islamabad see.PFV"=MSG PST CONDL
The English translation of this sentence is:`If only I had gone to Islamabad, it would have been good, I would have seen Islamabad.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Counterfactuality.} In counterfactual expressions, as in (\ref{ex:13-113})--(\ref{ex:13-114}), both the `if'-clause and the `then'-clause occur with the conditionality marker of low verisimilitude, heentá, i.e., the one also used in the hypothetical expressions above. The word áɡar in (\ref{ex:13-114}) is a~subordinating expression also occurring in Urdu conditionality \citep[101--103]{schmidt1999}.
A: word: yhóol-u	 gloss: come.PFV"=MSG
B: word: zára	 gloss: thousand.PL
C: word: áɡar	 gloss: if
D: word: yára	 gloss: if.only
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 295:

However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Question 300:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ tasíi dóodu ǰáand-u hín-u heentá tasíi úmur čuurbhišá kaal-á hóons-a
Gloss (with missing item): ___ 3SG.GEN grandfather alive-MSG be.PRS"=MSG CONDL 3SG.GEN age eighty year-PL stay-3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:`If his grandfather is still alive, he would be 80 years old.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The proposition in the `its gloss ___'-clause of (\ref{ex:13-114}) is contrary to fact, i.e., the person speaking knows for sure that the person referred to is dead. Therefore the `then'-clause here expresses what would have been the case its gloss ___ that had been otherwise. If the verisimilitude value, in constrast, is pending \citep[332]{givon2001b}, as is the case with the hypothetical conditionality exemplits gloss ___ied already, the proposition of the `then'-clause may still be true. A hypothetical conditionality contrasting with the counterfactuality in (\ref{ex:13-114}) can be seen in the almost parallel sentence in (\ref{ex:13-115}).
A: word: yára	 gloss: if.only
B: word: naɡarǰúti	 gloss: Nagarjuti
C: word: áɡar	 gloss: if
D: word: man"=ainíi	 gloss: say-VN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 304:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): áɡar tasíi dóodu ǰáand-u ___ heentá tasíi úmur čuurbhišá kaal-á hóons-a
Gloss (with missing item): if 3SG.GEN grandfather alive-MSG ___ CONDL 3SG.GEN age eighty year-PL stay-3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:`If his grandfather is still alive, he would be 80 years old.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The proposition in the `if'-clause of (\ref{ex:13-114}) is contrary to fact, i.e., the person speaking knows for sure that the person referred to is dead. Therefore the `then'-clause here expresses what would have been the case if that had been otherwise. If the verisimilitude value, in constrast, is pending \citep[332]{givon2001b}, as is the case with the hypothetical conditionality exemplified already, the proposition of the `then'-clause may still be true. A hypothetical conditionality contrasting with the counterfactuality in (\ref{ex:13-114}) can be seen in the almost parallel sentence in (\ref{ex:13-115}).
A: word: hín-u=ee	 gloss: be.PRS"=MSG=CNJ
B: word: hín-u	 gloss: be.PRS"=MSG
C: word: tháan-u	 gloss: do.PRS"=MSG
D: word: bhanǰóol-u	 gloss: beat.PFV"=MSG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 305:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): áɡar tasíi dóodu ǰáand-u hín-u ___ tasíi úmur čuurbhišá kaal-á hóons-a
Gloss (with missing item): if 3SG.GEN grandfather alive-MSG be.PRS"=MSG ___ 3SG.GEN age eighty year-PL stay-3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:`If his grandfather is still alive, he would be 80 years old.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The proposition in the `if'-clause of (\ref{ex:13-114}) is contrary to fact, i.e., the person speaking knows for sure that the person referred to is dead. A hypothetical conditionality contrasting with the counterfactuality in (\ref{ex:13-114}) can be seen in the almost parallel sentence in (\ref{ex:13-115}).

Question 306:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ šúi paaṇṭí bi ṣaá heensíl-u de xu bač na bhíl-u
Gloss (with missing item): ___ good.F clothes even put.on.CV stay.PFV"=MSG PST but saved NEG become.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Even though he was wearing good clothes, he did not survive.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Concessive clauses.} There is probably no unique strategy for forming concessive clauses. A conjunction with ``adversative'' reading (see \sectref{subsec:13-2-1}--\sectref{subsec:13-2-2}) can, for instance be used for this purpose, with (\ref{ex:13-118}) or without (\ref{ex:13-119}) the contrary"=to"=expectation particle bi `althe morpheme ___, even'.

B: word: tas	 gloss: 3SG.ACC
C: word: xaaneé	 gloss: shelf.PL
D: word: so	 gloss: 3SG.NOM
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 316:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ the bainií zhay-í ma ba laahur-á the ɡúum
Gloss (with missing item): ___ to go.VN place-OBL 1SG.NOM TOP Lahore-OBL to go.PFV.MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Instead of going to Karachi, I went to Lahore.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First, there are constructions involving the noun zhaáy `place'. The one exemplified in (\ref{ex:13-120}) has a~subordinate clause almost analogous to the English `instead of{\ldots}', with a~Verbal Noun qualifying the oblique form of zhaáy. The `place'-noun in (\ref{ex:13-121}) is on the other hand only qualified by a~possessive phrase and is therefore not a~subordinate clause at all.
A: word: karaačí	 gloss: Karachi
B: word: mhaás	 gloss: meat
C: word: islaamabaád	 gloss: Islamabad
D: word: baraaníi-e	 gloss: foreigner-GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

The `place'-noun in (\ref{ex:13-121}) is on the morpheme ___ othe morpheme ___r hand only qualified by a~possessive phrase and is the morpheme ___refore not a~subordinate clause at all.

Question 323:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ibrahiím aleehisalaam-íi putr ___ zhay-í míi dúudu qurbaán bhe hín-u
Gloss (with missing item): Ibrahim peace.be.upon.him-GEN son ___ place-OBL 1SG.GEN forefather sacrifice become.CV be.PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`My forefather was sacrificed instead [lit: in the place] of Ibrahim's, PBUH, son Ismail.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First, there are constructions involving the noun zhaáy `place'. The one exemplified in (\ref{ex:13-120}) has a~subordinate clause almost analogous to the English `instead of{\ldots}', with a~Verbal Noun qualifying the oblique form of zhaáy. The `place'-noun in (\ref{ex:13-121}) is on the other hand only qualified by a~possessive phrase and is therefore not a~subordinate clause at all.
A: word: ismaaíil-e	 gloss: Ismail-GEN
B: word: thíil-i	 gloss: do.PFV-F
C: word: tasíi	 gloss: 3SG.GEN
D: word: putr-íi	 gloss: son-GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 324:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ibrahiím aleehisalaam-íi putr ismaaíil-e ___ míi dúudu qurbaán bhe hín-u
Gloss (with missing item): Ibrahim peace.be.upon.him-GEN son Ismail-GEN ___ 1SG.GEN forefather sacrifice become.CV be.PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`My forefather was sacrificed instead [lit: in the place] of Ibrahim's, PBUH, son Ismail.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: First, there are constructions involving the noun zhaáy `place'. The one exemplified in (\ref{ex:13-120}) has a~subordinate clause almost analogous to the English `instead of{\ldots}', with a~Verbal Noun qualifying the oblique form of zhaáy. The `place'-noun in (\ref{ex:13-121}) is on the other hand only qualified by a~possessive phrase and is therefore not a~subordinate clause at all.
A: word: ṣač-í	 gloss: climb-CV
B: word: zhay-í	 gloss: place-OBL
C: word: ilaqaa-í	 gloss: area-OBL
D: word: khay-í	 gloss: which-F
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 325:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ the man"=ainií díi máa=the man"=ainií šóo de
Gloss (with missing item): ___ to say-VN from 1SG.NOM=to say-VN good.MSG be.PST
The English translation of this sentence is:`Rather than telling the police, you should have told me [lit: The telling to me is better than the telling to the police].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: It is also possible to use a~comparative construction `X-ing a, is better than X-ing b'. In this case, as seen in (\ref{ex:13-122}), both the subject head and the head of the predicate noun phrase are Verbal Nouns.
A: word: čoór	 gloss: thief
B: word: ɡir-áa	 gloss: turn-INF
C: word: pulusá	 gloss: police
D: word: axpul-aán	 gloss: relative-PL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although implicit to a~larger extent, a~substitutive reading of an~utterance"=complement with the direct"=quote the morpheme ___rker thaní (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}), is also possible ((\ref{ex:13-123})--(\ref{ex:13-124})) and the morpheme ___y very well be the preferred way of expressing substitution. In (\ref{ex:13-124}) this interpretation is supported by the word ulṭá `upside"=down'.

The English translation of this sentence is:`In the village, children and women were waiting for the menfolk who had gone hunting, expecting them to bring back meat. Instead, they brought back three corpses.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although implicit to a~larger extent, a~substitutive reading of an~utterance"=complement with the direct"=quote marker thaní (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}), is also possible ((\ref{ex:13-123})--(\ref{ex:13-124})) and may very well be the preferred way of expressing substitution. In (\ref{ex:13-124}) this interpretation is supported by the word ulṭá `upside"=down'.

D: word: déeš	 gloss: village
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 341:

However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): díiš-a ba baalbač-á kuṛíina táma th-éen de ___ bharíiw-a be hín-a neečíir the whaal-éen mhaas-á whaal-éen thaní hasé dees-á ulṭá hasé trúu ǰinaazeé ɡhin-í wháat-a xálak-a
Gloss (with missing item): village-OBL TOP child-PL woman.PL waiting do-3PL PST ___ husband-PL go.CV be.PRS"=MPL game to bring.down-3PL meat-PL bring.down.3PL QUOT REM day-OBL upside.down REM three corpse.PL take.CV come.down.PFV"=MPL people-PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`In the village, children and women were waiting for the menfolk who had gone hunting, expecting them to bring back meat. Instead, they brought back three corpses.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although implicit to a~larger extent, a~substitutive reading of an~utterance"=complement with the direct"=quote marker thaní (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}), is also possible ((\ref{ex:13-123})--(\ref{ex:13-124})) and may very well be the preferred way of expressing substitution. In (\ref{ex:13-124}) this interpretation is supported by the word ulṭá `upside"=down'.
A: word: biabeen-íim	 gloss: wilderness-PL.OBL
B: word: kasée	 gloss: whose
C: word: míi	 gloss: 1SG.GEN
D: word: asée	 gloss: 1PL.GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 356:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:`In the village, children and women were waiting for the menfolk who had gone hunting, expecting them to bring back meat. Instead, they brought back three corpses.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although implicit to a~larger extent, a~substitutive reading of an~utterance"=complement with the direct"=quote marker thaní (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}), is also possible ((\ref{ex:13-123})--(\ref{ex:13-124})) and may very well be the preferred way of expressing substitution. D: word: yh-íin	 gloss: come-3PL

However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:`Besides beating me up, he stole my money.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzthe morpheme ___rke{Additive clauses.} There is not much evidence of any entirely unique construction expressing additive sethe morpheme ___ntics. Instead the conjunction with \textit{bi{\ldots}bi} (see \sectref{subsec:13-2-1}) seems to cover some occurrences of ``addition''. Possibly the construction found in (\ref{ex:13-125}), with a~subordinate Verbal Noun followed by the postposition sanɡí `with' along with bi in the the morpheme ___in clause, represents a~more explicit expression of ``addition''.

D: word: maníit-u	 gloss: say.PFV"=MSG

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Additive clauses.} There is not much evidence of any entirely unique construction expressing additive semantics. Instead the conjunction with \textit{bi{\ldots}bi} (see \sectref{subsec:13-2-1}) seems to cover some occurrences of ``addition''. Possibly the construction found in (\ref{ex:13-125}), with a~subordinate Verbal Noun followed by the postposition sanɡí `with' along with bi in the main clause, represents a~more explicit expression of ``addition''.

Question 371:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): camel-OBL say.PFV"=MSG ___ lineage honour need NEG become-PRS-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`The camel said, ``There is no need here for lineage or honour.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Utterance predicates.} It is only with utterance predicates that the zero strategy ((i), above) may be used alone, and even then it occurs sparingly. According to my data, it is only the verb mané- `say, call, tell', as in (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-128}), that seems to allow it.
A: word: índa	 gloss: here
B: word: zamindaár	 gloss: farmer
C: word: atshareet-á	 gloss: Ashret-OBL
D: word: eetáa	 gloss: there
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Sentence (with missing item): míi maníit-u ki ___ tus b-óoi
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG.GEN say.PFV"=MSG COMP ___ 2PL.NOM go.IMP.PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`I said, ``That's fine, you may leave!'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: More frequently, the ki-strategy ((ii) above) is used, with mané- as well as with a~number of other utterance predicates (or predicates that in context imply an~utterance): (\ref{ex:13-129})--(\ref{ex:13-131}). Whenever ki is used as a~complementiser, the complement is heavy"=shifted to the end.
A: word: bhešóol-u	 gloss: sit.down.CAUS.PFV"=MSG
B: word: šišáw-u	 gloss: good-MSG
C: word: šóo	 gloss: good.MSG
D: word: waxt	 gloss: time
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 393:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): luumái čéɣi dít-i hín-i ki ___ amzarái ée karáaṛu ée iṇc̣ táru wh-óoi míi lhéṇḍ-u láad-u
Gloss (with missing item): fox cry give.PFV-F be.PRS-F COMP ___ lion o leopard o bear quickly come.down-IMP.PL 1SG.GEN bald-MSG find.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`The fox cried, ``O lion, o leopard, o bear, come quickly, I found the bald one.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Mits gloss ___re frequently, the ki-strategy ((ii) abits gloss ___ve) is used, with mané- as well as with a~number its gloss ___f its gloss ___ther utterance predicates (its gloss ___r predicates that in cits gloss ___ntext imply an~utterance): (\ref{ex:13-129})--(\ref{ex:13-131}). Whenever ki is used as a~cits gloss ___mplementiser, the cits gloss ___mplement is heavy"=shifted tits gloss ___ the end.
A: word: ée	 gloss: o
B: word: bulooṣṭéel-i	 gloss: snatch.PFV-F
C: word: theníi	 gloss: do.VN
D: word: dašúm	 gloss: ten.OBL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 404:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): uṭ-á maníit-u ___ násel izát pakaár na bh-éen-i
Gloss (with missing item): camel-OBL say.PFV"=MSG ___ lineage honour need NEG become-PRS-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`The camel said, ``There is no need here for lineage or honour.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always occur as direct quotations, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), or more correctly, they are always presented from a~quoted"=speaker's or experiencer's (i.e., the subject of the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, pronominal and time reference is concerned. Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a marginal exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').
A: word: índa	 gloss: here
B: word: zhay-í	 gloss: place-OBL
C: word: zamindaár	 gloss: farmer
D: word: eetáa	 gloss: there
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 408:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): uṭ-á maníit-u índa násel izát pakaár ___ bh-éen-i
Gloss (with missing item): camel-OBL say.PFV"=MSG here lineage honour need ___ become-PRS-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`The camel said, ``There is no need here for lineage or honour.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always occur as direct quotations, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), or more correctly, they are always presented from a~quoted"=speaker's or experiencer's (i.e., the subject of the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, pronomithe morpheme ___l and time reference is concerned. Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a margithe morpheme ___l exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').
A: word: ǰinaazá	 gloss: corpse
B: word: na	 gloss: NEG
C: word: níi	 gloss: 3SG.PROX.OBL
D: word: yeí	 gloss: come.CV
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 409:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): uṭ-á maníit-u índa násel izát pakaár na ___
Gloss (with missing item): camel-OBL say.PFV"=MSG here lineage honour need NEG ___
The English translation of this sentence is:`The camel said, ``There is no need here for lineage or honour.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always occur as direct quotations, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), or more correctly, they are always presented from a~quoted"=speaker's or experiencer's (i.e., the subject of the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, pronominal and time reference is concerned. Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a marginal exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').
A: word: bh-éen-i=ee	 gloss: become-PRS-F=CNJ
B: word: deníi	 gloss: give.VN
C: word: bh-éen-i	 gloss: become-PRS-F
D: word: hín-i	 gloss: be.PRS-F
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 410:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): luumái čéɣi dít-i hín-i ki ___ amzarái ée karáaṛu ée iṇc̣ táru wh-óoi míi lhéṇḍ-u láad-u
Gloss (with missing item): fox cry give.PFV-F be.PRS-F COMP ___ lion o leopard o bear quickly come.down-IMP.PL 1SG.GEN bald-MSG find.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`The fox cried, ``O lion, o leopard, o bear, come quickly, I found the bald one.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always its gloss ___ccur as direct quits gloss ___tatiits gloss ___ns, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), its gloss ___r mits gloss ___re cits gloss ___rrectly, they are always presented frits gloss ___m a~quits gloss ___ted"=speaker's its gloss ___r experiencer's (i.e., the subject its gloss ___f the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, prits gloss ___nits gloss ___minal and time reference is cits gloss ___ncerned. Nits gloss ___n"=its gloss ___ral perceptiits gloss ___n its gloss ___r cits gloss ___gnitiits gloss ___n\fits gloss ___its gloss ___tnits gloss ___te{It is prits gloss ___bably equally pits gloss ___ssible tits gloss ___ classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the prits gloss ___pits gloss ___sitiits gloss ___n be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way tits gloss ___its gloss ___, i.e., thits gloss ___ughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented frits gloss ___m the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered its gloss ___rally (a marginal exceptiits gloss ___n tits gloss ___ this is fits gloss ___und with what I refer tits gloss ___ belits gloss ___w as ``immediate perceptiits gloss ___n predicates'').
A: word: man"=ainíi	 gloss: say-VN

C: word: bulooṣṭéel-i	 gloss: snatch.PFV-F
D: word: ée	 gloss: o
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 411:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): luumái čéɣi dít-i hín-i ki ée ___ ée karáaṛu ée iṇc̣ táru wh-óoi míi lhéṇḍ-u láad-u
Gloss (with missing item): fox cry give.PFV-F be.PRS-F COMP o ___ o leopard o bear quickly come.down-IMP.PL 1SG.GEN bald-MSG find.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`The fox cried, ``O lion, o leopard, o bear, come quickly, I found the bald one.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always occur as direct quotations, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), or more correctly, they are always presented from a~quoted"=speaker's or experiencer's (i.e., the subject of the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, pronominal and time reference is concerned. Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a marginal exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').

B: word: biǰóol-a	 gloss: several-MPL
C: word: amzarái	 gloss: lion
D: word: amzarée	 gloss: lion.OBL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 413:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): luumái čéɣi dít-i hín-i ki ée amzarái ée ___ ée iṇc̣ táru wh-óoi míi lhéṇḍ-u láad-u
Gloss (with missing item): fox cry give.PFV-F be.PRS-F COMP o lion o ___ o bear quickly come.down-IMP.PL 1SG.GEN bald-MSG find.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`The fox cried, ``O lion, o leopard, o bear, come quickly, I found the bald one.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always occur as direct quotations, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), or more correctly, they are always presented from a~quoted"=speaker's or experiencer's (i.e., the subject of the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, pronominal and time reference is concerned. Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a marginal exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').
A: word: karáaṛu	 gloss: leopard
B: word: díi	 gloss: from
C: word: karáaṛ-a	 gloss: leopard-OBL
D: word: xučhá-ii	 gloss: Khush.Shah-GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 415:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): luumái čéɣi dít-i hín-i ki ée amzarái ée karáaṛu ée ___ táru wh-óoi míi lhéṇḍ-u láad-u

The English translation of this sentence is:`The fox cried, ``O lion, o leopard, o bear, come quickly, I found the bald one.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always occur as direct quotations, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), or more correctly, they are always presented from a~quoted"=speaker's or experiencer's (i.e., the subject of the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, pronominal and time reference is concerned. Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a marginal exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').
A: word: iṇc̣	 gloss: bear
B: word: íṇc̣-a	 gloss: bear-OBL
C: word: índa	 gloss: here
D: word: íṇc̣i-e	 gloss: bear-GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a marginal exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').

Question 421:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): áa deés se phoó xiaál thíil-i híni ki ___ čhoót míi se yaar-íi rumeel-í maǰí ɡhaṇḍ-í wíi-a keé-na ɡal-úum
Gloss (with missing item): one day DEF boy opinion do.PFV-F be.PRS-F COMP ___ cheese 1SG.GEN DEF friend-GEN handkerchief-OBL in tie-CV water-OBL why-NEG throw-1SG
The English translation of this sentence is:`One day the boy thought, ``Why don't I put some cheese in my friend's handkerchief and throw it into the water?'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Related utterances in Palula always occur as direct quotations, as can be seen in the examples (\ref{ex:13-127})--(\ref{ex:13-131}), or more correctly, they are always presented from a~quoted"=speaker's or experiencer's (i.e., the subject of the matrix clause) perspective, as far as deixis, pronominal and time reference is concerned. Non"=oral perception or cognition\footnote{It is probably equally possible to classify the predicate in a~sentence like this as desiderative~-- i.e., expressing a~desire that the proposition be realised~-- rather than as an~uttererance predicate.} is treated in this way too, i.e., thoughts, as in (\ref{ex:13-132}), are presented from the thinking agent's perspective, as if they were uttered orally (a marginal exception to this is found with what I refer to below as ``immediate perception predicates'').
A: word: khéli	 gloss: quite.some
B: word: tuúš	 gloss: some
C: word: bakáara	 gloss: flock
D: word: tus	 gloss: 2PL.NOM
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 432:

The English translation of this sentence is:`He threw dirt up [in the air], and said, ``Go on!'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While the complement of the utterance predicates mentioned so far are all extraposed (vis-à-vis the basic SOV word order), that is never allowed with any form of the verb thané- `say, call' (strategy~(iii) above), as in (\ref{ex:13-133})--(\ref{ex:13-134}). Note that, in example (\ref{ex:13-134}), the sentence with thaní is part of a~longer clause chain (see \sectref{sec:13-3}).

B: word: čo	 gloss: go.IMP.SG
C: word: ǰhuṭá	 gloss: dirty
D: word: pruɡraám	 gloss: programme
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 436:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): c̣hatróol"=ii xálak-a xošaán bhe aníi asíi ___ zindá thíil-u than-í taním bi baxšíš dít-i maṭaaíi-m ɡeél-i
Gloss (with missing item): Chitral-GEN people-PL happy become.CV 3SG.PROX.OBL 1PL.GEN ___ alive do.PFV"=MSG say-CV 3PL.ERG also award give.PFV-F sweets-PL throw.PFV-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`The Chitrali people became very happy, saying ``He has saved our reputation [lit: made our name live]'', and they also distributed gifts and sweets.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While the complement of the utterance predicates mentioned so far are all extraposed (vis-à-vis the basic SOV word order), that is never allowed with any form of the verb thané- `say, call' (strategy~(iii) above), as in (\ref{ex:13-133})--(\ref{ex:13-134}). Note that, in example (\ref{ex:13-134}), the sentence with thaní is part of a~longer clause chain (see \sectref{sec:13-3}).
A: word: putr-óom	 gloss: son-PL.OBL
B: word: nóo	 gloss: name
C: word: patá	 gloss: known
D: word: šúi	 gloss: good.F
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 437:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): Chitral-GEN people-PL happy become.CV 3SG.PROX.OBL 1PL.GEN name ___ do.PFV"=MSG say-CV 3PL.ERG also award give.PFV-F sweets-PL throw.PFV-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`The Chitrali people became very happy, saying ``He has saved our reputation [lit: made our name live]'', and they also distributed gifts and sweets.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: While the complement of the utterance predicates mentioned so far are all extraposed (vis-à-vis the basic SOV word order), that is never allowed with any form of the verb thané- `say, call' (strategy~(iii) above), as in (\ref{ex:13-133})--(\ref{ex:13-134}). Note that, in example (\ref{ex:13-134}), the sentence with thaní is part of a~longer clause chain (see \sectref{sec:13-3}).
A: word: xox	 gloss: liking
B: word: aaindá	 gloss: future
C: word: zarurí	 gloss: necessity
D: word: zindá	 gloss: alive
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 438:

However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:`The Chitrali people became very happy, saying ``He has saved our reputation [lit: made our name live]'', and they also distributed gifts and sweets.'

Question 439:

Question 444:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): deeúlii xálak"=am daawát dít-i atsharíit"=am the ki ___ th-íia thaníit-u ta atshareet-íi paalawaaṇ-aán ɡíia
Gloss (with missing item): Dir.GEN people-PL.OBL invitation give.PFV-F Ashreti-PL.OBL to COMP ___ do-1PL say.PFV"=MSG COMP Ashret-GEN wrestler-PL go.PFV.PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`The people fom Dir invited the Ashreti people, ``Let's have a~competition!'' And [having said that] the Ashreti strongmen left.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: utterance, which is the case in (\ref{ex:13-135}) and (\ref{ex:13-136}). It becomes, in effect,
A: word: parčá	 gloss: paper
B: word: muqaabilá	 gloss: contest
C: word: ṭinɡ	 gloss: challenge
D: word: muqarár	 gloss: fixing
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 445:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): deeúlii xálak"=am daawát dít-i atsharíit"=am the ki muqaabilá ___ thaníit-u ta atshareet-íi paalawaaṇ-aán ɡíia
Gloss (with missing item): Dir.GEN people-PL.OBL invitation give.PFV-F Ashreti-PL.OBL to COMP contest ___ say.PFV"=MSG COMP Ashret-GEN wrestler-PL go.PFV.PL
The English translation of this sentence is:`The people fom Dir invited the Ashreti people, ``Let's have a~competition!'' And [having said that] the Ashreti strongmen left.'

A: word: bh-íia	 gloss: become-1PL
B: word: th-íi	 gloss: do-3SG
C: word: th-íia	 gloss: do-1PL
D: word: tus	 gloss: 2PL.NOM
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 446:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): míi ba ṭeekíl-u ki ___ kaakaá óo kaakaá ínc̣-a čhéeli khéel-i thaní ta bhraáš pašambeé so bháaru čhúuṇ-u
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG.GEN TOP call.PFV"=MSG COMP ___ uncle o uncle bear-OBL goat eat.PFV-F QUOT SUB slowly Pashambi DEF.MSG.NOM load put.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`I called out, ``O uncle, the bear ate the goat'', whereby Pashambi slowly put down his load.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: utterance, which is the case in (\ref{ex:13-135}) and (\ref{ex:13-136}). It becits gloss ___mes, in effect,
A: word: bhróo	 gloss: brother
B: word: óo	 gloss: o
C: word: wáǰa	 gloss: reason
D: word: dašúm	 gloss: ten.OBL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 447:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): míi ba ṭeekíl-u ki óo ___ óo kaakaá ínc̣-a čhéeli khéel-i thaní ta bhraáš pašambeé so bháaru čhúuṇ-u
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG.GEN TOP call.PFV"=MSG COMP o ___ o uncle bear-OBL goat eat.PFV-F QUOT SUB slowly Pashambi DEF.MSG.NOM load put.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`I called out, ``O uncle, the bear ate the goat'', whereby Pashambi slowly put down his load.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: utterance, which is the case in (\ref{ex:13-135}) and (\ref{ex:13-136}). It becomes, in effect,
A: word: dóodu	 gloss: grandfather
B: word: kareé=ɡale	 gloss: when=ever
C: word: kaakaá	 gloss: uncle
D: word: akaadúi	 gloss: RECP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 452:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Question 453:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): se míiš-a soóč thíil-i ki ___ xu típa ma páta kh-óo thaní ba
Gloss (with missing item): DEF man-OBL thinking do.PFV-F COMP ___ however now 1SG.NOM surely eat-3SG QUOT TOP
The English translation of this sentence is:`The man thought that he would surely eat him too [lit: The man thought, ``He will surely eat me too'']. Having said that{\ldots}'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Propositional attitude predicates.} Closely related to and sometimes difficult to distinguish from utterance predicates are those predicates that express an~attitude regarding the complement proposition, especially concerning its verisimilitude. The particle xu (in examples (\ref{ex:13-137}) and (\ref{ex:13-138})) expresses certainty on the part of the subject of the matrix clause concerning the immediately preceding argument or phrase.
A: word: eesó	 gloss: 3MSG.REM.NOM
B: word: anú	 gloss: 3MSG.PROX.NOM
C: word: hanú	 gloss: 3MSG.PROX.NOM
D: word: taalím	 gloss: education
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 454:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): se míiš-a soóč thíil-i ki anú ___ típa ma páta kh-óo thaní ba
Gloss (with missing item): DEF man-OBL thinking do.PFV-F COMP 3MSG.PROX.NOM ___ now 1SG.NOM surely eat-3SG QUOT TOP
The English translation of this sentence is:`The man thought that he would surely eat him too [lit: The man thought, ``He will surely eat me too'']. Having said that{\ldots}'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Propositional attitude predicates.} Closely related to and sometimes difficult to distinguish from utterance predicates are those predicates that express an~attitude regarding the complement proposition, especially concerning its verisimilitude. The particle the morpheme ___ (in examples (\ref{ex:13-137}) and (\ref{ex:13-138})) expresses certainty on the part of the subject of the matrix clause concerning the immediately preceding argument or phrase.
A: word: xušaán	 gloss: happy
B: word: tus	 gloss: 2PL.NOM
C: word: rat-á	 gloss: blood-PL
D: word: xu	 gloss: however
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 472:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): o 1SG.GEN God.voc 3PL.PROX.NOM evidently camel-GEN foot.prints be.PRS-F well go.1SG PROX foot.prints catch-CV ___ CNTR QUOT
The English translation of this sentence is:`I thought, ``O my God! It's the footprints of a~camel! Well, in any case, I'll find out.'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Propositional attitude predicates.} Closely related to and sometimes difficult to distinguish from utterance predicates are those predicates that express an~attitude regarding the complement proposition, especially concerning its verisimilitude. The particle xu (in examples (\ref{ex:13-137}) and (\ref{ex:13-138})) expresses certainty on the part of the subject of the matrix clause concerning the immediately preceding argument or phrase.
A: word: ɡubáa-ii	 gloss: what-GEN
B: word: ɡubáa	 gloss: what
C: word: yaá=ba	 gloss: or=TOP
D: word: šay	 gloss: thing
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 474:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): so hairán bhíl-u ki ___ čhéelí dúu khur-áam ǰhulí keé uth-í hín-i thaní
Gloss (with missing item): 3MSG.NOM surprised become.PFV"=MSG COMP ___ goat two foot-PL.OBL on why stand.up-CV be.PRS-F QUOT
The English translation of this sentence is:`He was surprised that the goat was standing up on two feet.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Commentative predicates.} Commentative (or factive) predicates provide a~comment on a~complement proposition that is assumed to be real \citep[127--129]{noonan2007}. Again, the distinction between these and utterance predicates is not always very obvious, as the complement often occurs as reported discourse, and there is probably quite some overlap. Typically, the complement clause is formed as a~question, with keé `why' in (\ref{ex:13-140}) or kateeṇí `what kind' in (\ref{ex:13-141}).
A: word: aṛé	 gloss: DIST
B: word: eeṛáa	 gloss: there.DIST
C: word: ǰhaníi	 gloss: wedding.GEN
D: word: haṛé	 gloss: DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 489:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ak yúun padúši so xabár bhíl-u ki ___ hakim-á thíi so duṣmán nawaab-á ḍáḍi phreyíl-u thaní
Gloss (with missing item): one month after 3MSG.NOM informed become.PFV"=MSG COMP ___ ruler-OBL 2SG.GEN DEF.MSG.NOM enemy prince-OBL side send.PFV"=MSG QUOT
The English translation of this sentence is:`A month later he [the king] was informed that the ruler of Shishi had helped his [the king's] enemy to get to [the territory of] the prince [of Dir].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Predicates of knowledge acquisition.} Many complement"=taking predicates having to do with acquisition of knowledge use the same strategies as for utterances, and again the complement is presented as an~utterance (either by the agent of the matrix clause, as in (\ref{ex:13-143}), or by some other (explicit or implicit) source participant, as in (\ref{ex:13-144}) and (\ref{ex:13-145})), whether it is literally and verbally uttered or is merely cognitively processed, i.e., ``uttered'' mind"=internally.
A: word: sanɡi-eé	 gloss: with-INCL
B: word: rhootašíi-a	 gloss: morning-OBL
C: word: ɣulaamseedmalak-íi	 gloss: Ghulam.Seyd.Malak-GEN
D: word: šišíi-e	 gloss: Shishi-GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 490:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ak yúun padúši so xabár bhíl-u ki šišíi-e ___ thíi so duṣmán nawaab-á ḍáḍi phreyíl-u thaní
Gloss (with missing item): one month after 3MSG.NOM informed become.PFV"=MSG COMP Shishi-GEN ___ 2SG.GEN DEF.MSG.NOM enemy prince-OBL side send.PFV"=MSG QUOT
The English translation of this sentence is:`A month later he [the king] was informed that the ruler of Shishi had helped his [the king's] enemy to get to [the territory of] the prince [of Dir].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Predicates of knowledge acquisition.} Many complement"=taking predicates having to do with acquisition of knowledge use the same strategies as for utterances, and again the complement is presented as an~utterance (either by the agent of the matrix clause, as in (\ref{ex:13-143}), or by some other (explicit or implicit) source participant, as in (\ref{ex:13-144}) and (\ref{ex:13-145})), whether it is literally and verbally uttered or is merely cognitively processed, i.e., ``uttered'' mind"=internally.
A: word: hakim-í	 gloss: ruler-GEN
B: word: ux-íi	 gloss: camel-GEN
C: word: hakim-á	 gloss: ruler-OBL
D: word: asée	 gloss: 1PL.GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 501:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:`He heard from the beasts of the forest, that a~thing called ``man''....'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In examples (\ref{ex:13-143})--(\ref{ex:13-145}), the complement is presented as an~already uttered proposition. Even when the~-- assumedly verbal or cognitive~-- knowledge is still to be obtained, as perceived by the subject of the matrix clause, the same structure is utilised, which can be seen in (\ref{ex:13-146}) but now without the final thaní.
A: word: insaán=ee	 gloss: human.being=Q
B: word: ṣaa-wúuy=a	 gloss: put.on-IMP.PL=Q
C: word: insaán	 gloss: human
D: word: dít-i	 gloss: give.PFV"=FSG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

D: word: kateeṇ-ú	 gloss: what.kind-MSG

Correct Answer: D

Question 508:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): so insaán bulaḍ-íim bíi de páand-a pharé ki so insaán kateeṇ-ú ___ hín-u
Gloss (with missing item): DEF.MSG.NOM human find.out-CPRD go-3SG PST road-OBL along COMP DEF.MSG.NOM human what.kind-MSG ___ be.PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`He went ahead to find out what kind of thing man is.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In examples (\ref{ex:13-143})--(\ref{ex:13-145}), the complement is presented as an~already uttered proposition. Even when the~-- assumedly verbal or cognitive~-- knowledge is still to be obtained, as perceived by the subject of the matrix clause, the same structure is utilised, which can be seen in (\ref{ex:13-146}) but now without the final thaní.
A: word: kareé=ɡale	 gloss: when=ever
B: word: šaak-á	 gloss: wood-PL
C: word: šay	 gloss: thing
D: word: saamaán	 gloss: things
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 510:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): huṇḍɡiraá dac̣h-íin ta ___ muṭ-íi phúṭi ǰhulí bheš-í áaṇc̣-a kha-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): upward look-3PL SUB ___ tree-GEN top on sit-CV raspberry-PL eat-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`They looked up and there was the bear sitting in the top of the tree eating raspberries.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Immediate perception predicates.} With at least two verbs coding directly perceived events, dac̣h- `look, see' (in (\ref{ex:13-147})--(\ref{ex:13-148})) and dhay- `watch, note' (the latter only in B, (\ref{ex:13-149})), another construction is regularly used (strategy~(iv)), in which the finite complement"=taking predicate occurs with a~particle ta, followed by a~finite complement clause, i.e., the same construction used in the chaining of different"=subject clauses (see \sectref{sec:13-4}).
A: word: íṇc̣i-e	 gloss: bear-GEN
B: word: yaar-íi	 gloss: friend-GEN
C: word: íṇc̣-a	 gloss: bear-OBL
D: word: iṇc̣	 gloss: bear
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

C: word: kh-ainií	 gloss: eat-VN
D: word: eeṛáa	 gloss: there.REM
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 526:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): káakeṛ dhay-íi ta dúu peereṇíi-a hasé ___ pičha-aníi the yéel-im
Gloss (with missing item): Kakel note-3SG SUB two fairy-PL REM ___ sweep-VN to come.PFV"=FPL
The English translation of this sentence is:`Kakel noted that two fairies came to the graves to sweep them.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Immediate perception predicates.} With at least two verbs coding directly perceived events, dac̣h- `look, see' (in (\ref{ex:13-147})--(\ref{ex:13-148})) and dhay- `watch, note' (the latter only in B, (\ref{ex:13-149})), another construction is regularly used (strategy~(iv)), in which the finite complement"=taking predicate occurs with a~particle ta, followed by a~finite complement clause, i.e., the same construction used in the chaining of different"=subject clauses (see \sectref{sec:13-4}).
A: word: ziaarat-íim	 gloss: shrine-PL.OBL
B: word: ziaarat-í	 gloss: shrine-PL
C: word: baád	 gloss: after
D: word: iṇc̣	 gloss: bear
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 530:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): so šay ɡaḍ-í dac̣h-íi ta ___ dit-i=whaáu rumiaál hín-i
Gloss (with missing item): DEF.MSG.NOM thing take.off-CV look-3SG SUB ___ give.PPTC-F=ADJ handkerchief be.PRS-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`Taking up the thing and looking at it, she saw that it was the handkerchief she had given.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: It should be especially noted that while all the complements with PCU"=predicates exemplified in the previous sections represent direct discourse, the perceived event presented with this particular construction is indirect. Had it been presented as from the view of the experiencer in the matrix clause, the pronoun used in (\ref{ex:13-150}) would have been míi `my' and not the morpheme ___ `her'.
A: word: tasíi	 gloss: 3SG.GEN
B: word: eetasíi	 gloss: 3SG.GEN
C: word: lesée	 gloss: 3SG.DIST.GEN
D: word: teeṇíi	 gloss: REFL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 534:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): típa ___ haár d-ainií asíi mooqá hín-u
Gloss (with missing item): now ___ defeat give-VN 1PL.GEN opportunity be.PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Now we can defeat him [lit: Now is our opportunity to defeat him].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Necessity or ablility can also be expressed with complement clauses of complement"=taking nouns. In those cases, the Verbal Noun strategy (v) is used. This is exemplified in (\ref{ex:13-156})--(\ref{ex:13-159}).
A: word: las	 gloss: 3SG.DIST.ACC
B: word: tas	 gloss: 3SG.ACC
C: word: lasíi	 gloss: 3SG.DIST.GEN
D: word: ač-aníi	 gloss: enter-VN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A
