Question 537:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tíi ___ yh-ainií koošíš thíil-i
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG.OBL ___ come-VN attempt do.PFV-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`He tried to come yesterday.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Achievement predicates.} Although it is sometimes difficult to draw a~definite line between modal predicates of the ability type presented above and achievement predicates, the main difference in the typical cases lies in implicativity. While the modals above are non"=implicative, achievement predicates are implicative, i.e., signalling successful vs. failed performance/realisation. In any case, the Verbal Noun strategy seems to be, if not the only possible, at least the preferred one. Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-160})--(\ref{ex:13-161}). Some achievement predicates require a~postposition with the Verbal Noun.
A: word: aḍaphará	 gloss: halfways
B: word: aáǰ	 gloss: today
C: word: ɡhoóṣṭ	 gloss: house
D: word: dhoóṛ	 gloss: yesterday
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 543:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): pirsaahib-á ba inkaár thíil-i ___ phoó deníi díi
Gloss (with missing item): Pir.Sahib-OBL TOP refusal do.PFV-F ___ boy give.VN from
The English translation of this sentence is:`Pir Sahib refused to hand over the boy.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Normally the Verbal Noun complement is embedded into the matrix clause. The complement in (\ref{ex:13-161}), however, occurs after the matrix clause and is thus added explanatorily rather than being extraposed in a~strict sense.
A: word: báaba	 gloss: father.OBL
B: word: soóč	 gloss: thinking
C: word: so	 gloss: DEF.MSG.NOM
D: word: ɡéeḍ-i	 gloss: big-F
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 545:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): pirsaahib-á ba inkaár thíil-i so phoó ___ díi
Gloss (with missing item): Pir.Sahib-OBL TOP refusal do.PFV-F DEF.MSG.NOM boy ___ from
The English translation of this sentence is:`Pir Sahib refused to hand over the boy.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Normally the Verbal Noun complement is embedded into the matrix clause. The complement in (\ref{ex:13-161}), however, occurs after the matrix clause and is thus added explanatorily rather than being extraposed in a~strict sense.
A: word: d-ainií	 gloss: give-VN
B: word: deníi	 gloss: give.VN
C: word: theníi-e	 gloss: do.VN"=GEN
D: word: ninaám	 gloss: 3PL.PROX.ACC
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: One of those strategies is infinitival (vi), whereby the perfective form ṣáat- of the polysemous verb ṣač- `climb, etc.' is utilised (\ref{ex:13-166}).

Question 553:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ɣalí bhe ___ padúši bay-áa ṣéet-i
Gloss (with missing item): silent become.CV ___ behind go-INF begin.PFV-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`Silently she started to lag far behind.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Unlike the Infinitive"=taking modal bha- (see \textbf{Modal predicates} above), ṣáat- is confined to the perfective and remains intransitive, regardless of the transitivity of the complement predicate. In (\ref{ex:13-167}), with an~intransitive complement, as well as in (\ref{ex:13-168}), with a~transitive complement, the phasal verb agrees in gender and number with the subject of the matrix clause.
A: word: padúši	 gloss: behind
B: word: darwóoza	 gloss: door
C: word: maxadúši	 gloss: in.front.of
D: word: karáaṛu	 gloss: leopard
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

In (\ref{ex:13-167}), with an~intransitive complement, as well as in (\ref{ex:13-168}), with a~transitive complement, the phasal verb agrees in gender and number with the subject of the matrix clause.
A: word: eetáai	 gloss: from.there
B: word: yhaí	 gloss: come.CV

Question 561:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): IDEF thief 3SG.GEN house-OBL enter.PFV"=MSG ___ search-VN begin.PFV"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`A thief entered his house and started to search through the house.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although the construction is a~possible example of clause union, ṣáat- seems not to have morphologised to the same extent as bha-, evidenced also in the parallel use of a~Verbal Noun (\ref{ex:13-169}) with it instead of an~Infinitive.
A: word: ɡhooṣṭ-á	 gloss: house-OBL
B: word: ɡhoóṣṭ	 gloss: house
C: word: ɡhooṣṭ-íi	 gloss: house-GEN
D: word: heentá	 gloss: CONDL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 566:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): míḍ=ee ɡúu ___ dharíit-a
Gloss (with missing item): ram=CNJ bull ___ remain.PFV"=MPL
The English translation of this sentence is:`The ram and the bull stood looking [lit:having looked, remained].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: There is evidence, though scanty, that the phasal notion of continuation can be expressed through two (for the purpose) less usual strategies with the complement"=taking predicate dhar- `remain', one being a~converb (\ref{ex:13-171}) and the other a~Copredicative Participle (\ref{ex:13-172}).
A: word: paš-í	 gloss: see-CV
B: word: dac̣h-í	 gloss: look-CV
C: word: dac̣h-íi	 gloss: look-3SG
D: word: ǰéel-i	 gloss: give.birth.PFV-F
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:`She kept bleating.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: There is evidence, though scanty, that the phasal notion of continuation can be expressed through two (for the purpose) less usual strategies with the complement"=taking predicate dhar- `remain', one being a~converb (\ref{ex:13-171}) and the other a~Copredicative Participle (\ref{ex:13-172}).
A: word: karáaṛu	 gloss: leopard
B: word: the-íim	 gloss: do-CPRD
C: word: xalk-íim	 gloss: people-PL.OBL
D: word: dac̣h-íim	 gloss: look-CPRD

Question 584:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): uc̣hí ba se čúti-m-e zaríia baándi so baṭ húṇṭraak c̣huɡal-áan-u ___ kúuk-a se muṭ-á bheš-aníi the na uṛ-áan-u mhaás kh-ainíi the na uṛ-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): lift.up.CV TOP DEF paw-PL"=GEN means by DEF.MSG.NOM stone upward hurl-PRS"=MSG ___ crow-PL DEF tree-OBL sit.down-VN to NEG let-PRS"=MSG meat eat-VN to NEG let-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`After picking them up, it was throwing the stones upward with the help of his paws, not allowing the crows sit in the tree, not allowing them to eat the meat.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Permissive predicates.} When uṛí- `pour, let out' is uthe morpheme ___d as a complement"=taking verb, it occurs in two different constructions, both of them with permissive the morpheme ___mantics. One is the Verbal Noun strategy ((v)), also occurring in various other complement clauthe morpheme ___s (the morpheme ___e \the morpheme ___ctref{subthe morpheme ___c:13-5-1}), followed by the postposition the `to', as shown in (\ref{ex:13-178}) and (\ref{ex:13-179}). This is uthe morpheme ___d in the indicative.
A: word: seéb	 gloss: sir
B: word: bhe	 gloss: become.CV
C: word: laahur-á	 gloss: Lahore-OBL
D: word: se	 gloss: DEF
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 585:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): uc̣hí ba se čúti-m-e zaríia baándi so baṭ húṇṭraak c̣huɡal-áan-u se ___ se muṭ-á bheš-aníi the na uṛ-áan-u mhaás kh-ainíi the na uṛ-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): lift.up.CV TOP DEF paw-PL"=GEN means by DEF.MSG.NOM stone upward hurl-PRS"=MSG DEF ___ DEF tree-OBL sit.down-VN to NEG let-PRS"=MSG meat eat-VN to NEG let-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`After picking them up, it was throwing the stones upward with the help of his paws, not allowing the crows sit in the tree, not allowing them to eat the meat.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Permissive predicates.} When uṛí- `pour, let out' is used as a complement"=taking verb, it occurs in two different constructions, both of them with permissive semantics. One is the Verbal Noun strategy ((v)), also occurring in various other complement clauses (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}), followed by the postposition the `to', as shown in (\ref{ex:13-178}) and (\ref{ex:13-179}). This is used in the indicative.
A: word: qalánɡ	 gloss: tax
B: word: kúuk-a	 gloss: crow-PL
C: word: kúuk-e	 gloss: crow-GEN
D: word: ǰhaníi	 gloss: wedding.GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 589:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): uc̣hí ba se čúti-m-e zaríia baándi so baṭ húṇṭraak c̣huɡal-áan-u se kúuk-a se muṭ-á bheš-aníi ___ na uṛ-áan-u mhaás kh-ainíi the na uṛ-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): lift.up.CV TOP DEF paw-PL"=GEN means by DEF.MSG.NOM stone upward hurl-PRS"=MSG DEF crow-PL DEF tree-OBL sit.down-VN ___ NEG let-PRS"=MSG meat eat-VN to NEG let-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`After picking them up, it was throwing the stones upward with the help of his paws, not allowing the crows sit in the tree, not allowing them to eat the meat.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Permissive predicates.} When uṛí- `pour, let out' is used as a complement"=taking verb, it occurs in two different constructions, both of the morpheme ___m with permissive semantics. One is the morpheme ___ Verbal Noun strategy ((v)), also occurring in various othe morpheme ___r complement clauses (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}), followed by the morpheme ___ postposition the morpheme ___ `its gloss ___', as shown in (\ref{ex:13-178}) and (\ref{ex:13-179}). This is used in the morpheme ___ indicative.
A: word: the	 gloss: to
B: word: theníi-e	 gloss: do.VN"=GEN
C: word: maníit-u	 gloss: say.PFV"=MSG
D: word: khúna	 gloss: near.to
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 590:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:`After picking them up, it was throwing the stones upward with the help of his paws, not allowing the crows sit in the tree, not allowing them to eat the meat.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Permissive predicates.} When uṛí- `pour, let out' is used as a complement"=taking verb, it occurs in two different constructions, both of them with permissive semantics. One is the Verbal Noun strategy ((v)), also occurring in various other complement clauses (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}), followed by the postposition the `to', as shown in (\ref{ex:13-178}) and (\ref{ex:13-179}). This is used in the indicative.
A: word: mhaas-á	 gloss: meat-PL
B: word: mhaás	 gloss: meat
C: word: taalím	 gloss: education
D: word: mhaaranií	 gloss: kill.VN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Question 596:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ɡhaḍeeró miṭínɡ xátum bhíl-ii pahúrta ___ b-ainií the uṛ-íi=ee
Gloss (with missing item): elder meeting finished become.PPTC"=GEN after ___ go-VN to let-3SG=Q
The English translation of this sentence is:`Will the elder let us leave after the meeting is over?'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Note that the manipulee of the main verb is coreferent with the agent of the complement verb but is assigned case by the main verb, thus coded accusatively in (\ref{ex:13-179}).
A: word: asaám	 gloss: 1PL.ACC
B: word: tanaám	 gloss: 3PL.ACC
C: word: baasaá	 gloss: spend.night.CV
D: word: yaá	 gloss: or
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 599:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ṛo uṛí ta ___ d-íi
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG.DIST.NOM let.IMP.SG SUB ___ give-3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Let him sing!'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The other strategy, involving the particle ta (iv), is used in the Imperative, with the literal rendering `let x (out), and x will do y'. Whereas in the strategy above the complement clause is embedded, the complement clause in this construction, seen in (\ref{ex:13-180}), is S-like and extraposed. The main verb does not assign case to the manipulee/complement clause agent in this construction.
A: word: rhootašíi-a	 gloss: morning-OBL
B: word: rhoo-á	 gloss: song-PL
C: word: dac̣h-áaṭ-u	 gloss: look-AG"=MSG
D: word: rhoó	 gloss: song
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The other strategy, involving the particle ta (iv), is used in the Imperative, with the literal rendering `let x (out), and x will do y'. Whereas in the strategy above the complement clause is embedded, the complement clause in this construction, seen in (\ref{ex:13-180}), is S-like and extraposed. The main verb does not assign case to the manipulee/complement clause agent in this construction.

Question 601:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tas the ṭeekíl-u ki ___ c̣híitr-a kráam-a the báaya thaní
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG.ACC to call.out.PFV"=MSG COMP ___ field-OBL work-OBL to go.1PL QUOT
The English translation of this sentence is:`He called out to her to come out and go with him to work in the field.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Causative predicates.} While the most important means of expressing causativity is morphological~-- a~matter we will return to shortly~-- manipulation that involves a~lower degree of agentive control \citep[45]{givon2001b} is often expressed through what are basically utterance predicates, also using the same strategies. Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-181})--(\ref{ex:13-183}). Hereby the manner of causation or persuation is also made explicit \citep[136]{noonan2007}. The complement clause is either imperative or hortative.
A: word: nikh-á	 gloss: come.out--IMP.SG
B: word: nikhá	 gloss: come.out.IMP.SG
C: word: khaá	 gloss: eat.CV
D: word: nikhái	 gloss: get.out.INF
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 607:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): deeúl-ii xálak"=am daawát dít-i atsharíit"=am the ki muqaabilá ___
Gloss (with missing item): Dir-GEN people-PL.OBL invitation give.PFV-F Ashreti-PL.OBL to COMP contest ___
The English translation of this sentence is:`The people from Dir invited the Ashreti people to have a competition with them.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Causative predicates.} While the most important means of expressing causativity is morphological~-- a~matter we will return to shortly~-- manipulation that involves a~lower degree of agentive control \citep[45]{givon2001b} is often expressed through what are basically utterance predicates, also using the same strategies. Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-181})--(\ref{ex:13-183}). Hereby the manner of causation or persuation is also made explicit \citep[136]{noonan2007}. The complement clause is either imperative or hortative.
A: word: bh-íia	 gloss: become-1PL
B: word: th-íi	 gloss: do-3SG
C: word: hasó	 gloss: \textbf{REM.MSG.NOM}
D: word: th-íia	 gloss: do-1PL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 608:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): eesé zanɡal-í áa baṭ-á ǰhulí har-í so kuṇaák ___
Gloss (with missing item): 3SG.REM.OBL forest-OBL IDEF stone-OBL on take.away-CV DEF.MSG.NOM child ___
The English translation of this sentence is:`He took the child to a~stone in the forest and seated him.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: When, however, agent control is strong, the preferred strategy is to utilise the morphological causative construction per se. This can either be in the form of direct causation, in essence deriving a~transitive verb from an~intransitive (such as `make sit down, seat' from `sit down' in (\ref{ex:13-184}) and `hang (something)' from `hang (by itself)' in (\ref{ex:13-185})), or in the form of indirect causation (such as `have (someone) drink' from `drink' in (\ref{ex:13-185}), `have someone tell' from `tell something' in (\ref{ex:13-186}) and `have someone educated' from `educate (oneself)' in (\ref{ex:13-187})). With indirect causation, an~animate manipulee is marked by ṣaawaá, a~grammaticalisation of the converb of ṣaawá- `put on, dress, turn on'.
A: word: bhešóol-u	 gloss: sit.down.CAUS.PFV"=MSG
B: word: bhéṭ-u	 gloss: sit.down.PFV"=MSG
C: word: rhoó	 gloss: song
D: word: bheešóol-u	 gloss: seat.PFV"=MSG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 611:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ khayí xarčá dawóol-u hín-u eesó xarčá ɡhin-í{\ldots}
Gloss (with missing item): ___ which expenditure ask.for.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG REM.MSG.NOM expenditure take-CV
The English translation of this sentence is:`Taking the reimbursement that the father has demanded{\ldots}'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Most similar to the typical Urdu"=Hindi relative"=correlative construction are those sentences that have a~full NP in a~preposed modifying clause corresponding to a~full NP in the main clause. In (\ref{ex:13-188})--(\ref{ex:13-189}), the otherwise interrogatively used khayí `which' is used as an~adnominal relative pronoun, correlating with a~demonstrative from the remote set. Although the noun can be repeated in full in the main clause along with a~demonstrative, it can equally well be coreferenced by a~demonstrative alone.
A: word: míiš-a	 gloss: man-OBL
B: word: c̣hiír	 gloss: milk
C: word: báabu	 gloss: father
D: word: báaba	 gloss: father.OBL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 624:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tipúka ni ba ___ hín-a dhii-á díi khooǰ-ainií zarurí bh-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): nowadays 3PL.PROX.NOM TOP ___ be.PRS"=MPL daughter-OBL from ask-VN necessity become-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Nowadays there are those for whom it is necessary to ask their daughter [who she wants to be married to].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Some modifying clauses with adnominal the morpheme ___ are possibly embedded rather than preposed, as in (\ref{ex:13-190}), where we may further suggest that a~noun xálak `people' is the implicit head. However, the analysis is still pending in anticipation of more natural data of a~similar kind. It should also be noted that a~pronoun ni `they (here)' from the proximal set is being used and not one from the usual remote set.
A: word: khéel-i	 gloss: eat.PFV-F
B: word: khayí	 gloss: which
C: word: khay-í	 gloss: which-F
D: word: khayáak	 gloss: which.one
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 625:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): tipúka ni ba khayí ___ dhii-á díi khooǰ-ainií zarurí bh-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): nowadays 3PL.PROX.NOM TOP which ___ daughter-OBL from ask-VN necessity become-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Nowadays there are those for whom it is necessary to ask their daughter [who she wants to be married to].'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Some modifying clauses with adnominal khayí are possibly embedded rather than preposed, as in (\ref{ex:13-190}), where we may further suggest that a~noun xálak `people' is the implicit head. However, the analysis is still pending in anticipation of more natural data of a~similar kind. It should also be noted that a~pronoun ni `they (here)' from the proximal set is being used and not one from the usual remote set.
A: word: hín-u	 gloss: be.PRS"=MSG
B: word: th-áan-a	 gloss: do-PRS"=MPL
C: word: dúu	 gloss: two
D: word: hín-a	 gloss: be.PRS"=MPL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 634:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ máaṭu dhraǰaá ba šúul-a the phedíl-u heentá hasó kh-úu
Gloss (with missing item): ___ neck stretch.CV TOP sheaf-OBL to reach.PFV"=MSG CONDL 3MSG.REM.NOM eat-3SG
The English translation of this sentence is:`The one [of us] whose neck can reach the sheaf shall eat.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Quite similar to, and possibly not altogether distinct from, the relative clauses above are those that contain an~interrogative pronoun, often in combination with (or even fused with) an~indefinite word or particle ɡalá (B ɡalé) meaning `ever'. The resulting meaning is something like `whoever, whatever', referring to one in a~group of potential referents having a~non"=specific reference. The relative clause is often a~Conditional clause, and is therefore more clearly subordinate than the above described construction, and the correlative in the main clause is referred to with a~demonstrative or personal pronoun from the remote set (if at all explicit). Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-192})--(\ref{ex:13-194}).
A: word: ɡubáa-ii	 gloss: what-GEN
B: word: kasée=ɡale	 gloss: who.GEN=ever
C: word: whaal-éen	 gloss: bring.down.3PL
D: word: kasée	 gloss: whose
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 643:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ṣiúul-a ___ maníit-u ta lhooméi kaṇ th-íi de
Gloss (with missing item): jackal-OBL ___ say.PFV"=MSG SUB fox HOST do-3SG PST
The English translation of this sentence is:`Whatever the jackal told him, the fox gave heed to.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Quite similar to, and possibly not altogether distinct from, the relative clauses above are those that contain an~interrogative pronoun, often in combination with (or even fused with) an~indefinite word or particle ɡalá (B ɡalé) meaning `ever'. The resulting meaning is something like `whoever, whatever', referring to one in a~group of potential referents having a~non"=specific reference. The relative clause is often a~Conditional clause, and is therefore more clearly subordinate than the above described construction, and the correlative in the main clause is referred to with a~demonstrative or personal pronoun from the remote set (if at all explicit). Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-192})--(\ref{ex:13-194}).
A: word: kareé=ɡale	 gloss: when=ever
B: word: patú	 gloss: behind
C: word: ɡubáa=ɡale	 gloss: what=ever
D: word: kasée=ɡale	 gloss: who.GEN=ever
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 644:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ṣiúul-a ɡubáa=ɡale ___ ta lhooméi kaṇ th-íi de
Gloss (with missing item): jackal-OBL what=ever ___ SUB fox HOST do-3SG PST
The English translation of this sentence is:`Whatever the jackal told him, the fox gave heed to.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Quite similar to, and possibly not altogether distinct from, the relative clauses above are those that contain an~interrogative pronoun, often in combination with (or even fused with) an~indefinite word or particle ɡalá (B ɡalé) meaning `ever'. The resulting meaning is something like `whoever, whatever', referring to one in a~group of potential referents having a~non"=specific reference. The relative clause is often a~Conditional clause, and is therefore more clearly subordinate than the above described construction, and the correlative in the main clause is referred to with a~demonstrative or personal pronoun from the remote set (if at all explicit). Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-192})--(\ref{ex:13-194}).
A: word: míiš-ii	 gloss: man-GEN
B: word: thíil-u	 gloss: do.PFV"=MSG
C: word: maníit-u	 gloss: say.PFV"=MSG
D: word: thaníit-u	 gloss: say.PFV"=MSG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 645:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ṣiúul-a ɡubáa=ɡale maníit-u ___ lhooméi kaṇ th-íi de
Gloss (with missing item): jackal-OBL what=ever say.PFV"=MSG ___ fox HOST do-3SG PST
The English translation of this sentence is:`Whatever the jackal told him, the fox gave heed to.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Quite similar to, and possibly not altogether distinct from, the relative clauses above are those that conthe morpheme ___in an~interrogative pronoun, often in combination with (or even fused with) an~indefinite word or particle ɡalá (B ɡalé) meaning `ever'. The resulting meaning is something like `whoever, whatever', referring to one in a~group of potential referents having a~non"=specific reference. The relative clause is often a~Conditional clause, and is therefore more clearly subordinate than the above described construction, and the correlative in the main clause is referred to with a~demonstrative or personal pronoun from the remote set (if at all explicit). Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-192})--(\ref{ex:13-194}).
A: word: bh-íl-a	 gloss: become-PFV"=MPL
B: word: ta	 gloss: SUB
C: word: rhootašíi-a	 gloss: morning-OBL
D: word: biabeen-íim	 gloss: wilderness-PL.OBL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 646:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ húuši ziaát bh-íi de eendáa so musaafár šukhaáu teeṇíi huǰut-í pharé pail-óo de
Gloss (with missing item): ___ wind most become-3SG PST like.that DEF.MSG.NOM traveller coat REFL body-OBL toward fold-3SG PST
The English translation of this sentence is:`The stronger the wind blew, the more closely did the traveller fold his cloak around him.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: A similar construction (without ɡalá, and not explicitly conditional) can also be used with manner adverbials, as exemplified in (\ref{ex:13-195b}).
A: word: kanaá	 gloss: how
B: word: kanáa	 gloss: like.what
C: word: bhanǰ-ainíi-a	 gloss: beat-VN"=OBL
D: word: ɡubáa	 gloss: what
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 651:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ ɡhíin-i eesé paaṇṭí tíi qabúl thíil-i
Gloss (with missing item): ___ take.PFV-F REM clothes 3SG.OBL acceptance do.PFV-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`He accepted the clothes that I had bought.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The modifying clause may be indicative finite, as in examples (\ref{ex:13-196})--(\ref{ex:13-199}), with the positions direct object, oblique object coding source and transitive subject, as well as the oblique object coding recipient being relativised.
A: word: míiš	 gloss: man
B: word: thíi	 gloss: 2SG.GEN
C: word: maxadúši	 gloss: in.front.of
D: word: míi	 gloss: 1SG.GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 653:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): ___ REFL key-PL give.PFV-F PST REM.MSG.NOM boy diappeared become.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`The boy whom I gave my keys has disappeared.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The modifying clause may be indicative finite, as in examples (\ref{ex:13-196})--(\ref{ex:13-199}), with the positions direct object, oblique object coding source and transitive subject, as well as the oblique object coding recipient being relativised.

B: word: yára	 gloss: if.only
C: word: míiš	 gloss: man
D: word: thíi	 gloss: 2SG.GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 658:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

Gloss (with missing item): ___ stay.PFV"=MSG CONDL REM.MSG.NOM timber future for failed become-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`Such timber that has knots will be worthless in the future.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The modifying clause may also occur as a~preposed Conditional clause, in (\ref{ex:13-200}) relativising the possessor NP.
A: word: karáaṛu	 gloss: leopard
B: word: ráaǰ-a	 gloss: rope
C: word: áaṛu	 gloss: knot
D: word: c̣hiír	 gloss: milk

Correct Answer: C

Question 661:

However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option.

The English translation of this sentence is:`That which is squeezed out is called ``kashmeeni'''
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Another possibility, seen in (\ref{ex:13-201}) and (\ref{ex:13-202}), is to use preposed dependent Converb clauses for relativisation.

C: word: th-éen	 gloss: do-3PL
D: word: dhamareet-á	 gloss: Dhamaret-OBL

Question 663:

Question 665:

Question 671:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): muxáak zamanée ___ than-í ak díiš-a kaakeṛ than-í ak méeš heensíl-u de
Gloss (with missing item): before time.GEN ___ call-CV IDEF village-OBL Kakel call-CV IDEF man stay.PFV"=MSG PST
The English translation of this sentence is:`Once there was, in a village called Chakadham, a~man called Kakel.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Some constructions that technically are relativisations with a~preposed Converb clause are lexicalised to a~large extent, and they function as standard presentational constructions when new participants or places are introduced into a~discourse. Note in (\ref{ex:13-204}) that the coreferential noun phrases in the main clause are indefinite.
A: word: čakaaḍhám	 gloss: Chakadham
B: word: habibulaxaán	 gloss: Habibullah.Khan
C: word: šúi	 gloss: good.F
D: word: akaadúi	 gloss: RECP
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 679:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): ___ íṇc̣-a ǰhulí ɡa hín-u eeṛó míiš=ee
Gloss (with missing item): ___ bear-OBL on REL be.PRS"=MSG DIST.MSG.NOM man=Q
The English translation of this sentence is:`Is it the man who is sitting on the bear?'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Sometimes in gapped relative clauses, a~particle ɡa is used as a~complementiser or relativiser, otherwise occurring as an~indefinite (`some', `any') or an~adnominal interrogative (`what', `what kind of') pronoun. This particle or word is invariable and thus is not coreferential with the modified NP. Instead it seems to merely mark the modifying clause vis-à-vis the main clause. Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-205})--(\ref{ex:13-208}).
A: word: ṣaá	 gloss: put.on.CV
B: word: haṛé	 gloss: DIST
C: word: aṛé	 gloss: DIST
D: word: eeṛáa	 gloss: there.DIST
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

The English translation of this sentence is:`Above [the place] where you took Henrik, there was a~fort.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Sometimes in gapped relative clauses, a~particle the morpheme ___ is used as a~complementiser or relativiser, otherwise occurring as an~indefinite (`some', `any') or an~adnominal interrogative (`what', `what kind of') pronoun. This particle or word is invariable and thus is not coreferential with the modified NP. Instead it seems to merely mark the modifying clause vis-à-vis the main clause. Examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-205})--(\ref{ex:13-208}).
A: word: ɡa	 gloss: REL
B: word: th-áan-a	 gloss: do-PRS"=MPL
C: word: maníit-u	 gloss: say.PFV"=MSG
D: word: ɡaíl-u	 gloss: throw.PFV"=MSG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: There does not seem to be any significant covariation between the presence of this marker and any particular position being relativised, although it possibly is used more readily (and maybe even non"=optionally) when an~oblique constituent is relativised, such as the location in (\ref{ex:13-207}) and (\ref{ex:13-208}).

Question 702:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): so ɡiḍúuču paalawaáṇ ___ yambaáṭ ɡa ɡhin-í b-íi de eesó na ṣandíl-u maní
Gloss (with missing item): DEF.MSG.NOM Dameli.man strong.man ___ mill.stone REL take-CV go-3SG PST 3MSG.REM.NOM NEG take.up.challenge.PFV"=MSG HSAY
The English translation of this sentence is:`The strong man of Damel, who used to walk with the millstone, apparently didn't take up the challenge'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{ex:13-210}), the modifying string `who used to walk with the millstone' seems to function simultaneously as a~postposed non"=restrictive relative clause to `the Dameli strong man' and as a~preposed restrictive relative"=correlative clause to `that (one) didn't take up the challenge'.
A: word: so	 gloss: DEF
B: word: soóč	 gloss: thinking
C: word: ṣaá	 gloss: put.on.CV
D: word: híṛ-u	 gloss: take.away.PFV"=MSG
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: In (\ref{ex:13-210}), the modifying string `who used to walk with the millstone' seems to function simultaneously as a~postposed non"=restrictive relative clause to `the Dameli strong man' and as a~preposed restrictive relative"=correlative clause to `that (one) didn't take up the challenge'.
A: word: de	 gloss: PST
B: word: náhin-a	 gloss: NEG.be.PRS"=MPL
C: word: darwóoza	 gloss: door
D: word: deeúl-ii	 gloss: Dir-GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 712:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): anú ___ míi putr-á hanís the kitaáb dít-i hasó phoó
Gloss (with missing item): 3MSG.PROX.NOM ___ 1SG.GEN son-OBL 3SG.PROX.ACC to book give.PFV-F REM.MSG.NOM boy
The English translation of this sentence is:`This is the boy who my son gave a~book to yesterday.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Some data (\ref{ex:13-212})--(\ref{ex:13-214})) suggests the possibility of regular anaphoric (personal or demonstrative) pronouns being used in the modifying clause, whether preposed or postposed. The evidence, however, is too scanty to draw any definite conclusions. Suffice it to say that the positions being thus relativised are low on the accessibility hierarchy (postpositional object and possessor, respectively), which is fully in line with typological predictions (\citealt[147--148]{keenan1985}; \citealt[226]{andrews_relative2007}). On the other hand, we have examples of relativisation of recipient (\ref{ex:13-199}) as well as possessor (\ref{ex:13-200}) by gapping.
A: word: ɡhoóṣṭ	 gloss: house
B: word: theníi	 gloss: do.VN
C: word: dhoóṛ	 gloss: yesterday
D: word: aáǰ	 gloss: today
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

A: word: thíi	 gloss: 2SG.GEN

C: word: míi	 gloss: 1SG.GEN
D: word: nóo	 gloss: name
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 725:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): míi ___ kili-á dít-i de eesó phoó phus bhíl-u hín-u
Gloss (with missing item): 1SG.GEN ___ key-PL give.PFV-F PST REM.MSG.NOM boy diappeared become.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`The boy whom I gave my keys has disappeared.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Some data (\ref{ex:13-212})--(\ref{ex:13-214})) suggests the possibility of regular anaphoric (personal or demonstrative) pronouns being used in the modifying clause, whether preposed or postposed. The evidence, however, is too scanty to draw any definite conclusions. Suffice it to say that the positions being thus relativised are low on the accessibility hierarchy (postpositional object and possessor, respectively), which is fully in line with typological predictions (\citealt[147--148]{keenan1985}; \citealt[226]{andrews_relative2007}). On the other hand, we have examples of relativisation of recipient (\ref{ex:13-199}) as well as possessor (\ref{ex:13-200}) by gapping.
A: word: teeṇíi	 gloss: REFL
B: word: teṇ-teeṇíi	 gloss: RED-REFL
C: word: čooṇṭéel-i	 gloss: embroider.PPTC-F
D: word: teeṇ-teeṇíi	 gloss: RED"=REFL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 732:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): rhootašíi-a ___ har"=ainií waxt yhóol-u ta
Gloss (with missing item): morning-OBL ___ take.away-VN time come.PFV"=MSG SUB
The English translation of this sentence is:`In the morning, at the time of taking the bride{\ldots}'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: A less"=accessible noun phrase may be expressed through nominalisation, whereby a~Verbal Noun becomes the possessor of the relativised entity. This seems to be especially common with time, location and means, as seen in (\ref{ex:13-215})--(\ref{ex:13-218}). The genitive case of the Verbal Noun is only explicitly present in the B variety (-e), whereas the genitive has been levelled in A.
A: word: ɡhambúri-m	 gloss: flower-PL
B: word: kaná	 gloss: shoulder.OBL
C: word: ǰanǰ	 gloss: wedding.party
D: word: ǰhambréeṛi	 gloss: bride
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: D

Question 734:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): phaí ___ háat"=am čooṇṭéel-i rumiaál dít-i hín-i
Gloss (with missing item): girl ___ hand-INS embroider.PPTC-F handkerchief give.PFV-F be.PRS-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`The girl gave [him] a handkerchief, which she had embroidered herself.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Less commonly, Perfective Participles may be used attributively, as in (\ref{ex:13-219})--(\ref{ex:13-221}), and in those cases, the participials relativise the direct object. As an~additional means of distinguishing the participle from the formally identical finite perfective verb, an~explicit (but optional) participial marker (also referred to as an~adjectiviser in this work), such as bhaáu in (\ref{ex:13-221}), can be used.
A: word: teeṇíi	 gloss: REFL
B: word: teeṇ-teeṇíi	 gloss: RED"=REFL
C: word: man"=ainií	 gloss: say-VN
D: word: teṇ-teeṇíi	 gloss: RED-REFL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Alternatively, the present"=tense verb is itself used without an~overt head, as in (\ref{ex:13-223}). This has an~implicit habituality read into it, whereas the corresponding non"=habitual meaning would have to be expressed with an~explicit correlative head (\ref{ex:13-224}).

Question 743:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): anú eesó míiš ki ___ se kúṛi mheeríl-i
Gloss (with missing item): 3MSG.PROX.NOM REM.MSG.NOM man COMP ___ DEF woman kill.PFV-F
The English translation of this sentence is:`This is the man who killed the woman.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: The possibility of extraposing a~modifying clause is facilitated by the particle or complementiser ki (see \sectref{subsec:13-5-1}). The sentences in (\ref{ex:13-225})--(\ref{ex:13-227}) are all elicited, and are thus not necessarily the most natural way of expressing these ideas. However, regarding them as a~general indication of grammaticality, we can conclude that the construction works for a~number of different positions. Note also that the emphatic or demonstrative pronoun is used in the main clause, whereas a~non"=emphatic anaphoric pronoun is used in the modifying ki-clause, although the latter is optional for the subject position.
A: word: theníi-e	 gloss: do.VN"=GEN
B: word: níi	 gloss: 3SG.PROX.OBL
C: word: táma	 gloss: waiting
D: word: aníi=wee	 gloss: 3SG.PROX.OBL=in
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

The English translation of this sentence is:` ``A blind knee'' is what we call a~goat or a~goat kid which is weak.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Nominal.} ki-clauses that correlate to a nominal element in the main clause are primarily heavy"=shifting, as can be seen in (\ref{ex:13-228})--(\ref{ex:13-230}).

B: word: trók-u	 gloss: weak-MSG

Some examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-231})--(\ref{ex:13-234}).

You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): anú míiš eetí maldaár ki nisíi ɡhooṣṭ-á ___ c̣hiír bi lhayiǰ-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): PROX.MSG.NOM man so.much wealthy COMP 3SG.PROX.GEN house-OBL ___ milk also be.found-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`This man is so rich that you even find sparrow's milk in his house.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Adjectival.} ki-clauses that correlate to an adjectival element in the main clause express comparison or provide exemplification or specification. Some examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-231})--(\ref{ex:13-234}).
A: word: kareé=ɡale	 gloss: when=ever
B: word: múṭii	 gloss: arm.GEN
C: word: čailúṭii	 gloss: sparrow.GEN
D: word: kúuk-e	 gloss: crow-GEN
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 767:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): áak eeteeṇ-ú waxt yhóol-u ki ___ wée xálak biǰóol-a bh-íl-a
Gloss (with missing item): IDEF like.that-MSG time come.PFV"=MSG COMP ___ in people several-MPL become-PFV"=MPL
The English translation of this sentence is:`This was the time when the population in Ashret had started to increase.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: \spitzmarke{Adjectival.} ki-clauses that correlate to an adjectival element in the main clause express comparison or provide exemplification or specification. Some examples are given in (\ref{ex:13-231})--(\ref{ex:13-234}).
A: word: atshareet-íi	 gloss: Ashret-GEN
B: word: atshareet-á	 gloss: Ashret-OBL
C: word: čhéelí	 gloss: goat
D: word: atsharíit"=am	 gloss: Ashreti-PL.OBL
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: B

Question 772:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): súun-a hatáwuu pándee haans-áan-a ki ___ súun-a bakáara xušán haans-éen-i šidaloó haans-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): pasture-OBL from.there for stay-PRS"=MPL COMP ___ pasture-OBL flock happy stay-PRS-F coldness stay-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`They stay in the high pasture, since their flock is happy there, where it is cold.'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although not examples of relativisation in a~strict sense, it should be noted that the same construction is used with clause adverbials (as has already been illustrated many times before). In (\ref{ex:13-235}) the ki-clause corresponds to a~reason, and in (\ref{ex:13-236}) it serves as an~explanation.
A: word: béeriṣ-a	 gloss: summer-OBL
B: word: múṛ-im	 gloss: die.PFV"=FPL
C: word: yúun-a	 gloss: month-OBL
D: word: kaṭéeri	 gloss: knife
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: A

Question 777:
You are a linguist specializing in Palula. You are given a sentence along with its morpheme breakdown, gloss, and translation. Words are separated by spaces, and morphemes are separated by hyphens. However, a word and its gloss are missing and represented by an underscore. Based on your understanding, please choose the most appropriate option. 
Sentence (with missing item): kareé eeṛé pruɡraám bhíl-i pahúrta eendáa th-áan-a ki ___ ǰhaníi deés muqarár bh-áan-u
Gloss (with missing item): when DIST programme become.PFV-F after like.that do-PRS"=MPL COMP ___ wedding.GEN day fixing become-PRS"=MSG
The English translation of this sentence is:`After that programme has taken place, then we do the following: we fix a~day [for the wedding]'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although not examples of relativisation in a~strict sense, it should be noted that the same construction is used with clause adverbials (as has already been illustrated many times before). In (\ref{ex:13-235}) the ki-clause corresponds to a~reason, and in (\ref{ex:13-236}) it serves as an~explanation.
A: word: oór	 gloss: and
B: word: rumiaál	 gloss: handkerchief
C: word: théeba	 gloss: then
D: word: thée	 gloss: then
Please only return the letter (A–D). Do not say anything else.
Correct Answer: C

Question 781:

The English translation of this sentence is:`After that programme has taken place, then we do the following: we fix a~day [for the wedding]'
Here is a relevant knowledge point for this example, with the related morphemes and glosses masked: Although not examples of relativisation in a~strict sense, it should be noted that the same construction is used with clause adverbials (as has already been illustrated many times before).
